articles.headline: Lumberjack, Tailor, Counselor, Host: A Hotel Owner Does It All in the Pandemic
articles.snippet: The head of a family business is trying to keep eight hotel properties afloat despite fewer travelers and worried lenders. He may not succeed.
articles.abstract: The head of a family business is trying to keep eight hotel properties afloat despite fewer travelers and worried lenders. He may not succeed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the pandemic began, Montu Patel has learned how to sew masks and fight with Wall Street lenders. He has helped draft pleas for relief to state and local officials on behalf of small-business owners. He knows how to fashion plexiglass.

articles.headline: Trump Took $70,000 in Tax Deductions for Hair Care. Experts Say That’s Illegal.
articles.snippet: It’s a small but telling detail in The Times’s exposé on the president’s taxes.
articles.abstract: It’s a small but telling detail in The Times’s exposé on the president’s taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: There were many bombshells in The New York Times’s exposé last week about President Trump’s taxes. He has paid basically zero federal income tax for years. His much-ballyhooed businesses are on the ropes. And that was just the headline.

articles.headline: House Lawmakers Condemn Big Tech’s ‘Monopoly Power’ and Urge Their Breakups
articles.snippet: In a report led by Democrats, lawmakers said Apple, Amazon, Google and Facebook needed to be checked and recommended they be restructured and that antitrust laws be reformed.
articles.abstract: In a report led by Democrats, lawmakers said Apple, Amazon, Google and Facebook needed to be checked and recommended they be restructured and that antitrust laws be reformed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House lawmakers who spent the last 16 months investigating the practices of the world’s largest technology companies said on Tuesday that Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google had exercised and abused their monopoly power and called for the most sweeping changes to antitrust laws in half a century.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe

articles.headline: Facebook Amps Up Its Crackdown on QAnon
articles.snippet: The company said an earlier effort to curb the conspiracy movement’s growth didn’t properly address its increasing popularity.
articles.abstract: The company said an earlier effort to curb the conspiracy movement’s growth didn’t properly address its increasing popularity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook, facing criticism that it hasn’t done enough to curb a fast-growing, fringe conspiracy movement, said on Tuesday that it would remove any group, page or Instagram account that openly identified with QAnon.

articles.headline: Trump’s Return Leaves White House in Disarray as Infections Jolt West Wing
articles.snippet: The West Wing was mostly empty, cleared of aides who were sick or told to work from home, and staff in the White House residence were in full personal protective equipment.
articles.abstract: The West Wing was mostly empty, cleared of aides who were sick or told to work from home, and staff in the White House residence were in full personal protective equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The White House that President Trump woke up in on Tuesday morning was in full-blown chaos, even by the standards of the havoc of the Trump era.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni

articles.headline: The Virus Surges in North Dakota, Filling Hospitals and Testing Attitudes
articles.snippet: As Covid-19 cases grow in the Great Plains, one official said residents need to know “how perilously close we are to the edge.”
articles.abstract: As Covid-19 cases grow in the Great Plains, one official said residents need to know “how perilously close we are to the edge.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BISMARCK, N.D. — When Tammy Gimbel called to check on her 86-year-old father two weeks ago, he sounded weak. He was rushed to Sanford Medical Center in North Dakota’s capital, where doctors said he had the coronavirus. But all the hospital beds in Bismarck were full, his relatives were told, and the only options were to send him to a hospital hours away in Fargo, or to release him to be monitored by his daughter, who was herself sick with the virus.

articles.headline: An Arms Dealer, an Ex-N.F.L. Player and Huge Federal Contracts for Medical Gowns
articles.snippet: The Trump administration awarded hundreds of millions of dollars’ worth of urgent work to small companies with scant experience.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration awarded hundreds of millions of dollars’ worth of urgent work to small companies with scant experience.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Defense Department distributed more than $1 billion in federal contracts last month to companies for disposable medical gowns to protect those on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Venezuela, Once an Oil Giant, Reaches the End of an Era
articles.snippet: Venezuela’s oil reserves, the world’s largest, transformed the country and the global energy market. Now its oil sector is grinding to a halt. Will it ever recover?
articles.abstract: Venezuela’s oil reserves, the world’s largest, transformed the country and the global energy market. Now its oil sector is grinding to a halt. Will it ever recover?
articles.lead_paragraph: CABIMAS, Venezuela — For the first time in a century, there are no rigs searching for oil in Venezuela.
articles.byline: By Sheyla Urdaneta, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
